page.title: 11FELTWELL SINCE WORLD WAR TWO
page.content: Feltwell is a large village and would have remained totally rural had it not been for its connection with aviation, beginning in 1917. In World War Two the R.A.F. had Lancasters and Wellingtons stationed here. This brought many airmen to the village. Many of the people stayed, that meant more children and a new school was built. Old residents told us that some of the old shops, such as shoemaker, baker, basketmaker and blacksmith had long since disappeared from Feltwell. The old public houses such as the Cock Inn, Crown and Bell have gone; the picture house 'Crazy Horse' is now a storage building. New estates such as Oakfields, Manor Park and St. Nicholas have been built in the 1970s and brought in people from far and wide.
